newsitem.title: UK: Cocoa futures ruffled by September options expiry.
newsitem.headline: Cocoa futures ruffled by September options expiry.

text.p: The upcoming expiry of September options sent shivers through the London cocoa ring on Wednesday as players weighed the risk of an out-of-the money declaration.
Particularly posing a threat were the 1,050 stg calls, which, being just 15 stg away from the futures price, could be exercised by longs trying to agitate the market, traders said.
Nervous dealings in anticipation of possible options-related short covering sent futures prices sharply higher in early trade as September leaped to a session high of 1,039 stg a tonne.
This was its highest level since July 10.
"There is a risk 1,050 will be exercised," said one options trader. "September is vulnerable to be tested at that level."
By the close on Tuesday, the open position on the 1,050 call was 970 lots, or 9,700 tonnes of cocoa, and puts were 850 lots.
Options holders have to decide whether to exercise their positions during Tuesday's midday interval from 1130 GMT.
Market turbulence stems from a hefty long position on the September futures contract of about 30,000 lots or 300,000 tonnes of cocoa, believed to be held by one big player.
The prospect of a record delivery in September had rallied September to an eight year high of 1,172 stg in June but a steady flow of cocoa from Ivory Coast eased the pressure.
But traders are now saying the long house could use the options as one of its last weapons to squeeze the market.
"The market believes that the long holder has the 1,050, 1,100 and 1,200 strikes and he will try to push the market up to create new September shorts," said one trader.
This suggested that the 1,050 call could be exercised even if the futures price and the premium does not justify it.
"I wouldn't be surprised. The long would be saying (to the shorts) you better find 10,000 tonnes of cocoa," said one.
But others disagreed, saying that the 1,050 strike was possibly controlled by a host of other players and a concerted action was difficult.
"I don't think the long house has more than 500 lots on 1,050 and that's not enough to squeeze the market," said another trader.
Traders said 1,100 calls where open interest is 1,092 lots could be another threat but an out-of-the-money exercise looks unlikely unless the futures market rises to that level.
